awd_titl_txt: UNS:  Surfactant Herders for Containment and Remediation of Maritime Oil Spills
awd_abstract_narration:
CBET - 1512458
PI: Maldarelli, Charles

Maritime oil spills can pose serious hazards to marine life and coastal shorelines.  The goal of this project is to develop biodegradable surfactants for use in "chemical herding" as an effective oil spill response.  In this method of containment, surfactants are sprayed aerially into uncontaminated water immediately outside the spill.  The surfactants lower the air-water surface tension, which causes the floating oil layer to retract and thicken to the point that it can be removed by burning or mechanical skimming.  The investigators will synthesize surfactant herders that are easily degraded and conduct experiments to evaluate their performance in laboratory simulations of chemical herding.
 
Surfactants will be synthesized using naturally occurring terpenoids with a unique single carbon branch repeating structure as the hydrophobic tail and a polar head group attached with an ester group that hydrolyzes after the herding action.  The air/water surface tension reduction by the herder will be measured.  An alternative strategy in which the surfactant is used to lower the oil/water interfacial tension, leading to retraction of the oil layer, will also be investigated.  The herding capabilities of the surfactants will be demonstrated in laboratory experiments and compared with the performance of commercially available surfactants currently in use.

por.por_cntn:
This research grant studied the process of chemical herding as a method for remediating maritime oil spills. In chemical herding, surfactant  (soap molecules) are spread around the periphery of the spill to compress the oil layer so that it can be burned or skimmed off the surface. The most successful chemical herders developed to date are synthetic surfactants which testing has shown has limited biodegradation and the potential to bioaccumulate. In addition, all herders have to date been developed to be effective in the reduction of the sea surface tension, without regard to formulations which promote and are effective in wave dissipation.

The overall goal of the research program has been to develop, as a first principle, eco-friendly (green) surfactant herder formulations by using natural marine surfactants. The formulation is specifically targeted to be able to not only significantly reduce the sea surface tension, but be effective in rough sea environments.

This study has established that two surfactant molecules which are present in the marine biota, the isoprenoid fatty acid phytanic acid and the unsaturated glycolipid  MGDG found in the chloroplasts of plants are extremely effective as chemical herders for the remediation of maritime oil spills. This study demonstrated in miniaturized (pan scale) experiments that these molecules, when spread as a monolayer around a crude oil lens floating on an air/water interface, can develop sufficient surface pressures to compress and thicken  the lens so that it can easily be removed (e.g. by burning). The pan scale experiments also demonstrated that this herding is steadfast and  the monolayer retains its spreading pressure over extended times. These ecofriendly, easily resourced  molecules, offer an alternative to the currently used surfactant herders which do not degrade readily in a marine environment and can have potential harmful effects on marine life.

The study provided an understanding of why MGDG and phytanic acid  are so effective at herding. Measurements of the surface pressure isotherms demonstrated that these amphiphiles, with either unsaturated  or isoprenoid hydrophobic chains, form monolayers which remain in a liquid state on compression, thereby generating large values of the surface pressure over a wide range of areas per molecule. In addition, the liquid state insures that upon collapse, the surface remains constant and the monolayer does not disintegrate with a large reduction in pressure.  The liquid state of these amphiphiles also demonstrated a large dilatational surface viscosity, which enables the herder to dampen surface waves and remain effective under rough sea conditions. Molecular studies of the monolayers using nanoscopic imaging (atomic force microscopy) and x-ray reflectivity provided a molecular picture of the layer, in particular the thicknesses of the hydrophobic layer above the interface, and the hydrophilic layer in contact with water below the surface which lends to an understanding of its fluidity.

 This study assesses for the first time the potentially important role of  sea polysaccharides and the divalent sea salts on the herding process. The study established that the polysaccharides can complex to the hydrophilic groups of the herding monolayer, thereby expanding the layer and increasing the surface pressure. This process can be enhanced by the presence of divalent cations which can act as a bridge between the negatively charged polysaccharide (sea polysaccharides are usually negatively charged) and the hydrophilic group of the surfactant if it is negatively charged (e.g. a carboxylate of a fatty acid, as in this study). The complexation also enhances the stability and increases the dilatational viscosity of the monolayer, and both of these effects increase the herding efficacy. Thus amphiphiles which can strongly bind the polysaccharides are a class of molecules which can potentially be effective as chemical herders. In this study, the glycolipid with the hydroxyl groups of the galactose polar part of the amphiphile allowed for strong dipole-charge interactions with the polysaccharide, and the phytanic acid, in the presence of calcium, provided an even greater binding  due to cation bridging between the carboxylate and the polysaccharide.
